if you know something more about filters do let me know :) The whole 
filter thing seems to be too confusing and even after spending 4-5 
hours today I am not able to get it to work as of my understanding.

I am just trying to crawl pages whose URI match a certain pattern but 
no luck. Either thecrawler doesnt crawl pages beyond the seed or it 
seems to crawl everything.



--- In archive-crawler@yahoogroups.com, "gsellek" <gsellek@y...> 
wrote:
> 
> Hello,
> 
> This time I'm trying to narrow my crawls down to html.  Tom 
> emerson's doc in the FAQ is not available at the moment, so I'm 
> guessing on how to do this.
> 
> I've added the content type regex filters to my midfetch and ARC 
> writers, which seems to be working.  But, non text is still getting 
> added to my frontier, which means I crawl (and then abort) a lot of 
> things I don't need.
> 
> So, I was going to add a postselector regex filter to only add text 
> back into the frontier to crawl.  But, the filters have me 
confused, 
> and it does not seem to be behaving as I would expect.
> 
> I have the following settings:
> 
> filters ? Filters applied to this processor 
>         URI ? URI regexp filter. 
>           enabled:  ?    True  
>           if-match-return:  ?  True  
>           regexp:  ? .*
> 
(\.gif|\.jpeg|\.jpg|\.mov|\.bmp|\.pic|\.png|\.tiff|\.tif|\.css|\.js|\
> .swf|\.qt|\.mpeg|\.mpg|\.mp3|\.avi|\.wav|\.wmv|\.pdf|\.doc|\.xls|\.c
s
> v|\.ppt)$   
>       seed-redirects-new-seed:  ?  True  
>       override-logger:  ?    True 
> 
> The thought being if it matches the regex then don't add it into 
the 
> frontier.  If I set the if-match-return to True, nothing seems to 
> get added to it.  But, if I set it to false, a lot of .gif 
> and .jpegs are getting in.  I guess I just don't understand this 
> whole filter thing.
> 
> Any ideas?  (In general, I'd rather use a regex to filter out 
things 
> as above rather than in, but that could be done if necessary)
> 
> Thanks,
> Greg
